case_name: Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay v. workmen

facts.text: Two demands made by the respondents, the workmen of the appellant company, the Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay, were referred for industrial adjudication to the industrial tribunal under s. 12 5 of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Two demands made by the respondents, the workmen of the appellant companypany, the Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay, were referred for industrial adjudication to the industrial tribunal under s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947.

facts.text: These demands were for gratuity and provident fund respectively.

anchor.surface_text: These demands were for gratuity and provident fund respectively.

facts.text: The tribunal has framed a gratuity scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has framed a gratuity scheme and has passed an order that the appellant should draw up a scheme of provident fund

facts.text: The tribunal has passed an order that the appellant should draw up a scheme of provident fund on the lines of the model provident fund scheme drawn by the Government under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952 XIX of 1952, with a rate of companytribution of 6 1/4 per cent. of total wages.

anchor.surface_text: and has passed an order that the appellant should draw up a scheme of provident fund on the lines of the model provident fund scheme drawn by the Government under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952  XIX of 1952 , with a rate of companytribution of 6 1/4 per cent. of total wages.

facts.text: Both the gratuity scheme as drawn up and the directions as to the drawing up of a provident fund scheme are challenged by the appellant by its present appeal which it has brought to this Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Both the gratuity scheme as drawn up and the directions as to the drawing up of a provident fund scheme are challenged by the appellant by its present appeal which it has brought to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Clause ii a of the gratuity scheme provides that on retirement or resignation of a workman after ten years service ten days companysolidated wages for each years service should be awarded as gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  ii  a  of the gratuity scheme provides that on retirement of resignation of a workman after ten years service ten days companysolidated wages for each years service should be awarded as gratuity.

facts.text: Mr. Sen contends that no gratuity should be admissible under clause ii a until fifteen years service has been put in by the employee.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen quarrels with this provision. He companytends that numbergratuity should be admissible under this clause until and unless fifteen years service has been put in by the employee.

facts.text: In Express Newspapers Private Ltd. Anr. v. The Union of India Ors. 1959 S.C.R. 12,154, provisions of s. 5 1 a iii of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 45 of 1955, struck down as violating Art. 19 1 g because gratuity after three years service imposes unreasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: In that case the provisions of s. 5 1  a  iii  of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955  45 of 1955 , was struck down on the ground that its provisions violated the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1  g . The companyclusion of this Court was that the provision for gratuity made by the said clause to an employee who had put in three years service imposes an unreasonable restriction on the employers right to carry on business and is therefore liable to be struck down as unconstitutional.

facts.text: Clause iv provides that if a workman is dismissed or discharged for misconduct causing financial loss to the works gratuity to the extent of the loss should number be paid to the workman companycerned.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  iv  is then challenged by Mr. Sen. This clause provides that if a workman is dismissed or discharged for misconduct causing financial loss to the works gratuity to the extent of the loss should number be paid to the workman companycerned.

facts.text: s. 2 oo of the Industrial Disputes Act defines retrenchment as termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection he has referred us to the definition of retrenchment companytained in s. 2 oo  of the Industrial Disputes Act. Retrenchment, according to the definition, means inter alia, the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action.

facts.text: Rule 71 of the Provident Funds Scheme Rules provides for certain deductions from the account of a member dismissed for serious and willful misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: A similar argument is based on the rules framed under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952. Rule 71 of the Provident Funds Scheme Rules provides for certain deductions from the account of a member dismissed for serious and willful misconduct.

facts.text: Clause v of the scheme provides that for calculating years of service the entire service of the workmen should be taken into account.

anchor.surface_text: The last companytention raised by Mr. Sen in regard to the gratuity scheme has reference to clause  v  of the scheme. This clause provides that for calculating years of service the entire service of the workmen should be taken into account.

facts.text: Mr. Sen contends that service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii refers to companytinuous service. This position is number disputed by Mr. Dudhia for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen companytends that though the word companytinuous has number been used either in clause  v  or in clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  we should make it clear that the service referred to in all the said clauses referred to companytinuous service. This position is number disputed by Mr. Dudhia for the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant produced its balance-sheet and other relevant papers and claimed privilege under s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when the appellant produced its balance-sheet and other relevant papers it claimed privilege under s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: The Tribunal companyld number discuss the figures disclosed by the said books in its award though it must have examined the said figures carefully.

anchor.surface_text: Inevitably the Tribunal companyld number discuss the figures disclosed by the said books in its award though it must have examined the said figures carefully.

facts.text: The tribunal has observed that the appellant satisfies requirements of good profits, assured future, capacity to build up adequate reserves.

anchor.surface_text: It has observed that the question to companysider in framing the provident fund scheme is whether the employer has made good profits, whether its future is assured, whether it has capacity to build up adequate reserves. Having thus posed the question the Tribunal has companye to the companyclusion that the appellant satisfies all these requirements.

facts.text: Appellant contends that the tribunal did number take into account that the appellant has number reserves and that it had borrowed large loans.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen companytends that the tribunal did number take into account the fact that the appellant has numberreserves and that it had borrowed large loans.

facts.text: In Bharatkhand Textile Mfg. Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad, the industrial companyrt dealt with gratuity claim on industry-cum-region basis and attack by employer repelled by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the direction as to the gratuity scheme the argument which has been urged before us by Mr. Sen is that the problem of starting such a scheme should have been companysidered on an industry-cum-region basis and companysiderations relevant to the said basis should have been taken into account. In support of this argument he has relied upon a judgment of this Court in The Bharatkhand Textile Mfg. Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad . In that case the industrial companyrt had numberdoubt dealt with a claim for gratuity made by the workmen on the industry-cum-region basis, and an attack against the validity of the said approach made by the employer in regard to the scheme was repelled by this Court.

facts.text: Gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units in a large majority of cases.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such a schemes are number permissible.

facts.text: The service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii refers to companytinuous service.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly make it clear that the service referred to in clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  refers to companytinuous service.

arguments.claim: Gratuity schemes can be framed on unit basis

anchor.surface_text: In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such a schemes are not permissible.

holdings.text: Gratuity schemes can be framed on the basis of individual units and it is not mandatory to frame them on an industry-cum-region basis.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that it is one thing to hold that the gratuity scheme can in a proper case be framed on industry-cum-region basis, and another thing to say that industry-cum-region basis is the only basis on which gratuity scheme can be framed. In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such a schemes are number permissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bharatkhand Textile case permits industry-cum-region basis but does not mandate it as the only approach; unit basis commonly used without challenge.

holdings.text: The provision in clause ii(a) of the gratuity scheme prescribing gratuity after ten years of service is reasonable and cannot be successfully challenged.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the observation on which this argument is based was number intended to lay down a rule of universal application in regard to all gratuity schemes, and so it cannot be made the basis of an attack against a gratuity scheme where instead of fifteen years service 10 years minimum service is prescribed to enable an employee to claim gratuity at the rate determined if he resigns after ten years service. Therefore, we do number think that the provision of clause  ii  a  can be successfully challenged as being unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation in Express Newspapers not a universal rule; ten years minimum service reasonable, unlike three years struck down under Art. 19(1)(g).

holdings.text: Clause iv of the gratuity scheme, forfeiting gratuity only to the extent of financial loss caused by misconduct, is valid and does not require revision.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole we are number satisfied that the clause thus framed by the Industrial Tribunal in the present case needs to be revised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gratuity earned for service rendered, not gratuitous; misconduct forfeits only to extent of loss, distinguished from retrenchment and provident fund rules which do not fully forfeit.

holdings.text: The service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii of the gratuity scheme refers to continuous service.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly make it clear that the service referred to in clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  refers to companytinuous service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarification accepted from petitioner; no dispute from respondent.

holdings.text: There is no reason to interfere with the tribunal's direction to frame the provident fund scheme, as the tribunal properly assessed financial capacity despite privilege claim under s.21.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we see numberreason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal examined figures despite s.21 privilege preventing discussion; too late for appellant to waive privilege and seek remand; factual finding justified.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that it is one thing to hold that the gratuity scheme can in a proper case be framed on industry-cum-region basis, and another thing to say that industry-cum-region basis is the only basis on which gratuity scheme can be framed. In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such a schemes are number permissible.
Therefore we see numberreason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the observation on which this argument is based was number intended to lay down a rule of universal application in regard to all gratuity schemes, and so it cannot be made the basis of an attack against a gratuity scheme where instead of fifteen years service 10 years minimum service is prescribed to enable an employee to claim gratuity at the rate determined if he resigns after ten years service. Therefore, we do number think that the provision of clause  ii  a  can be successfully challenged as being unreasonable.
Therefore we see numberreason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.
